title: Esports expand rural students' chance for professional career
text:
The crowd goes wild as Fergus Steers rounds the final bend and heads for the home straight; the chequered flag flashes as he crosses the line.

Except 14-year-old Fergus is not driving a car, he is playing a video game.

Fergus Steers was one of 80 students competing at the Riverina FUSE Cup championships. (ABC Riverina: Nicola Ceccato)

"I qualified for the quarterfinals, so I was pretty happy about that since I was a little bit rusty," Fergus said.

The Yanco Agricultural High School student was among 80 students from eight schools and 11 teams who competed at the inaugural Riverina FUSE Cup competition in the south-west NSW town of Leeton earlier this month.

It was the first time an esports event had been held in rural New South Wales.

"It feels good to prove to people in the city that the bush kids can play. It's not always the city kids [that] are the best," Fergus said.

More than a race

Students battled it out at the Leeton Roxy Theatre for the Riverina FUSE Cup title. (ABC Riverina: Nicola Ceccato)

The competition is part of a push to promote a safe online environment and strategies for young people to navigate the online world.

"A lot of the digital wellbeing we are talking about can be anything based around cyberbullying — if a stranger approaches you online … [or] image-based abuse — and making sure that everybody is aware of what is going on online," said FUSE Cup operations coordinator Kristen Cummins.

Kristen Cummins is pleased with the level of skill shown by Riverina school students. (ABC Riverina: Nicola Ceccato)

Ms Cummins said opportunities for gaming careers were growing, and it was important the FUSE Cup reached out to regional and rural areas to include them in this growth.

"It doesn't matter where you come from; you can always have the ability to represent the country if you have the time, dedication and skill," she said.

Gaming industry revenue has increased by 200 per cent in Australia since 2016, according to a 2024 Australia Game Development Industry snapshot report.

The number of game development employees in Australia had also increased by over 192 per cent during that time.

Opportunities for esports and gaming professions continue to grow globally. (ABC Riverina: Nicola Ceccato)

Ms Cummins said that with the addition of more worldwide competitions and the inaugural 2027 Esports World Cup in Saudi Arabia, there could be opportunities to play professionally.

"Esports is just growing bigger and bigger every day, I would say, globally," she said.

It is a career 16-year-old Jack Curry hoped could be an option.

Jack Curry hopes to go on to win the state and then the national champs. (ABC Riverina: Nicola Ceccato)

The Leeton High School student won the Riverina FUSE Cup and will compete in the state finals on the Gold Coast next month.

"I think it's a pretty good way, at least for me, to try and find other competitors," Jack said.

"If I lose to them I will try and strive to get better than them. So that's the kind of relationship I get from a lot of these tournaments.

"This is the first time I've made it so far in a tournament, and I'm really stoked to follow through.

"If I'm going to nationals, I need to at least make it past the first round."

Shaiila Ogilvie says the positive camaraderie is good to see in the competition. (ABC Riverina: Nicola Ceccato)

But like any good sporting event, there was more to the competition than winning.

"Everyone's kept their temper, or if they don't win, they're not sad about it, not angry or anything," said Shaiila Ogilvie from St Francis College.

"They're just happy and understanding for the [winning] team.

"No-one's yelled at anyone. They've all fist bumped and said 'good job'."

title: Nationals ditch net zero support in party platform
text:
The Nationals have removed support for net zero from their federal platform amid mounting expectations their federal MPs are poised to do the same.

A meeting of the party’s Federal Council in Canberra on Saturday cemented the change, which was widely regarded as a formality, given that every state branch of the party had already passed similar motions.

While the federal platform does not bind the Nationals’ federal party room, its members appear close to landing on a similar position, with some speculation that could happen as early as this week.

The motion called on the parliamentary party to “abandon” support for achieving net zero emissions but retains support for “emissions reductions”, which it says should be balanced with “growing and protecting key industries such as the mining, agriculture and manufacturing sectors”.

It calls for a “balanced energy mix, including coal, gas and renewable energy sources” and an end to the federal moratorium on nuclear energy.

Divisions between Coalition parties and within them

About 35 Liberals gathered in Canberra on Friday to discuss energy policy, with sources inside the meeting telling the ABC they were cautiously optimistic about reaching a consensus position.

But Liberals are nervous their Coalition colleagues could use this motion as a pretext to front-run their joint process and take a Nationals-only stance on net zero as soon as their Monday party room meeting.

The issue has split moderates and conservatives within Liberal ranks and has also created frustrations among Nationals.

Barnaby Joyce has described himself as a “free agent” and is taking time away from the Nationals party room, in part due to a deterioration in relation with leader David Littleproud but also motivated by his strident opposition to net zero.

Speaking from South Korea, where he is attending the APEC Summit, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese described the Coalition’s net zero process as a “circus” and out of step with global developments.

“The world is getting on with the transition to net zero," he said.

"Overwhelmingly, the world sees that the transition to net zero [and] climate change is real."

title: Scientists work to unravel mystery tick illness hitting Australians
text:
Over three decades as a GP in northern Sydney, Richard Schloeffel saw thousands of patients with complex chronic diseases.

Many lived with myalgic encephalomyelitis/chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS), while others struggled with long COVID.

But it was a group of patients with debilitating, ongoing symptoms linked to tick bites that prompted the now-retired GP to undertake further research.

"I think tick-borne illness can be treated," Dr Schloeffel, now a researcher at Macquarie University, said.

" It's just that you have to believe the patient is sick in the first place. "

Most common DSCATT symptoms: fatigue

disordered thinking

sensory disturbance

joint pain

headache. Source: Department of Health, Disability and Ageing

Once described as "Lyme-like illness", thousands of Australians have reported suffering persistent symptoms, including fatigue, joint pain and neurological problems, they believe to be the result of a tick bite.

In 2018, the federal Department of Health coined the term DSCATT — debilitating symptom complexes attributed to ticks — to recognise these patients, and established clinical recommendations to help doctors manage them.

But the cause of their symptoms, and how best to treat them, remains highly contested in the medical and scientific community.

Earlier this year, a Senate inquiry found many patients struggled to access care and sometimes spent thousands of dollars, including on unproven testing and treatment, to find answers.

"Most people in Australia who get a tick bite don't get sick. We're talking about the tip of the iceberg," Dr Schloeffel, who has long advocated for patients with tick-bite associated illnesses, said.

But for those who do report illness, many struggle to feel believed or seen.

"People bankrupt themselves to find treatment and get diagnosed," Dr Schloeffel said.

Ticks are parasites that feed on blood from animals and humans. (Pexels: Erik Karits)

Following an earlier Senate inquiry in 2016, the federal government awarded funding to Australian researchers to investigate the causes of DSCATT and potential treatments.

Scientists have been slowly making inroads, but many questions remain unanswered.

Tick-borne diseases in Australia

There are around 70 species of ticks in Australia, 17 of which bite humans, Peter Irwin, a veterinary scientist and tick researcher at Murdoch University, said.

While usually harmless, tick bites can cause a range of illnesses, including allergic reactions, bacterial infections and, less commonly, paralysis.

"On the east coast of Australia, the main tick is the Australian paralysis tick (Ixodes holocyclus)," Professor Irwin said.

"The other main tick of medical importance is the kangaroo tick (Amblyomma triguttatum), which lives almost all over Australia."

Bitten by a tick? Here's what to do Ticks can make you really sick, so how do you remove them safely?

Allergies are the most common adverse reaction to tick bites, and range from mild (lasting a few days) to severe (including life-threatening anaphylaxis).

In some cases, people develop mammalian meat allergy (also known as alpha-gal syndrome) after a tick bite, which results in them no longer being able to eat red meat and other products derived from mammals.

Ticks can also carry Rickettsia bacteria, which cause infections including Queensland tick typhus, Flinders Island spotted fever, and Australian spotted fever.

These infections are most commonly seen in people who live in high-risk areas such as northern Sydney, and are usually treated with a short course of antibiotics.

Is Lyme disease in Australia?

In recent years, a growing number of Australians have reported suffering debilitating, ongoing symptoms they believe to be the consequence of a tick bite — but their illnesses cannot be easily diagnosed or treated.

In some cases, people believe they have contracted Lyme disease, a tick-borne infection commonly found in parts of the US, Europe and Asia, which can sometimes lead to persistent symptoms like severe fatigue, muscle pain and cognitive problems.

But according to Professor Irwin, there is no evidence that the infection can be acquired in Australia as no Australian ticks have been found to carry Borrelia burdorferi, the bacterium responsible for Lyme disease.

"There's nothing difficult about finding Borrelia bacteria overseas, and of course, there is Lyme disease overseas," Professor Irwin said.

"But in Australia … no-one has ever been able to find Borrelia burgorferi."

What to know about Justin Timberlake's Lyme disease diagnosis Singer Justin Timberlake reveals his struggle with the disease during his recent world tour.

Other Borrelia species have been identified in Australia, but it is not known whether they can be transmitted to humans by ticks.

Without local evidence of Borrelia burgdorferi, the diagnosis of locally acquired Lyme disease is not supported by Australian health authorities.

Adding to the challenge is the fact DSCATT symptoms can overlap with other infectious and chronic diseases, and not everyone affected has a clear history of a tick bite.

Symptoms of patients with lingering health issues who do not meet the criteria for a recognised disease or infection are usually deemed "medically unexplained" — and treatment options are limited.

"What DSCATT guidelines do is … basically stop any further investigation or treatment being available," Dr Schloeffel said.

One of the recommendations of this year's Senate inquiry was to replace the current DSCATT clinical pathway with new guidelines.

"That patients continue to experience debilitating and severe symptoms and that patients are left without a diagnosis or treatment plan is of serious concern," the final report noted.

Searching for an answer

To understand what might be causing some people to experience ongoing, "medically unexplained" symptoms, Professor Irwin and his colleagues at Murdoch University received funding in 2019 to closely track Australians after they received a tick bite.

"The idea was to perhaps find which of the Australian microorganisms could be the equivalent of Lyme Borrelia bacteria overseas," Professor Irwin said.

The research team followed 118 people over 12 months, taking blood samples and skin biopsies, and studying the ticks responsible for the bites.

"We sampled people within 72 hours of a tick bite … and then again at one week, three months, and 12 months, with the idea we would monitor them for all sorts of things to try to detect patterns, biological processes, infections and so on."

DSCATT symptoms include fatigue, headaches, disordered thinking and joint pain. (Pexels: Shivansh Sharma)

The results of the study, which was delayed by COVID, are due to be peer-reviewed and published in the coming months. But preliminary findings suggest a small number of participants experienced symptoms "similar to those reported by DSCATT patients" at 12 months, Professor Irwin said.

"[They had] migraines, headaches, dizziness — the sorts of signs that have been attributed to ticks."

In addition to looking for new pathogens, Professor Irwin said the research team was investigating whether known bacteria, viruses and parasites could be causing long-term illness.

"Some of our patients developed evidence of rickettsial infection, as you'd expect, and we're looking very hard to see whether any of those patients went on to develop DSCATT symptoms," he said.

"The question is: could [an infection] have caused an acute localised or even systematic reaction, and has that triggered — in some people — the propensity to develop DSCATT symptoms?

"That's what we're trying to unravel."

Diagnosing and treating an invisible illness

The question of if — and how — tick-borne diseases cause chronic infection, inflammation or other ongoing biological changes is something scientists overseas are also investigating.

The current uncertainty, and lack of scientific evidence, is why "chronic Lyme disease" is a disputed and controversial diagnosis. Instead, health authorities, including the US Centers for Disease Control (CDC), use the term "post-treatment Lyme disease syndrome" to describe people who experience prolonged symptoms.

"Chronic Lyme disease … implies that prolonged symptoms are caused by an ongoing bacterial infection when, in fact, the cause is not currently known," the agency noted.

ABC Health in your Instagram feed Follow @abchealth on Instagram, where we're busting myths and sharing practical, smart health advice.

In Australia, patients with unexplained chronic symptoms linked to tick bites generally do not show any evidence of infection or irregularities in standard blood tests, Dr Schloeffel said.

"There's this general belief that if you can't measure something, they look alright and they've tested normal, there is nothing wrong with them."

The former GP believes the lack of pathological evidence is a reflection of inadequate diagnostic testing, not the absence of disease, and is something he is working on trying to improve.

"The gap in the patient being sick and the doctor's belief that they're sick is the blood test. We don't have to diagnose them," he said.

According to Dr Schloeffel, possible mechanisms driving the persistence of symptoms — which would be missed in standard blood tests — include infection-induced immune dysfunction and chronic inflammation inside cells.

Through a privately funded clinical trial at Royal North Shore Hospital in Sydney, Dr Schloeffel and his colleagues are monitoring a range of biomarkers in 60 DCSATT patients in the hope of establishing new diagnostic markers and tests.

They are also evaluating the benefits of treating some patients with low-dose, long-term antibiotics — a treatment that is not recommended by health authorities in Australia, and described as having "known harm and no benefit" in current treatment guidelines.

In its submission to the 2024 Senate inquiry, the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners (RACGP) noted that "negotiating diagnostic uncertainty" could be challenging and frustrating for patients, but there was "little or no evidence to support specific treatments for tick-borne diseases".

"We need to be mindful that unnecessary medications, testing or procedures are low-value care and can cause more harm than benefit."

Focus on improving quality of life

In 2019, alongside funding the Murdoch University study, the government also awarded University of Melbourne researchers a grant to investigate whether a psychology-based intervention could help people with DSCATT manage their illness.

Richard Kanaan, a professor of psychiatry and research leader, said the nine-month therapy — designed to be given in addition to other treatments or supportive care — was developed with a goal to improve patients' quality of life.

The intervention was adapted from existing approaches used to help treat other chronic and complex illnesses where the cause was unclear.

People with chronic symptoms attributed to ticks are often living in turmoil because their illness cannot be easily diagnosed and treated. (Getty Images: wenjin chen)

"The treatment is one that has been tried successfully with a number of similar diseases … where people get an infection, think of the infection itself as being short-lasting, but the after-effects can go on for a long time and be very debilitating," Professor Kanaan said.

"We're not necessarily talking about a cure, because people … may go on having the illness. But we're talking about improvement."

In coming months, the researchers will assess the feasibility of the intervention they have developed — which is based on acceptance and commitment therapy — and evaluate whether it has any therapeutic effects.

Professor Kanaan said the research team had received some criticism from people with DSCATT concerned about the psychological nature of the treatment — and implication their illness was being viewed as a "disease of the mind", not the body.

"People are concerned it's being considered a psychiatric illness, and by extension, it's 'all in the head' — that the illness is being hallucinated or people are making it up," he said.

"I absolutely do not believe that."

The term DSCATT itself has been widely criticised by patients, in part because it defines symptoms as being "attributed" to — rather than caused by — ticks. This year's Senate inquiry also recommended the term be replaced.

Professor Kanaan said investigating the benefits of psychological therapy in no way reduced the seriousness of the illness.

"Why psychiatry is involved is because understanding a complex problem — it needs a holistic approach," Professor Kanaan said.

"As much as we'd like there to be a very simple explanation … it doesn't seem to be that kind of problem."

title: Road to isolated community considered for repair after three years
text:
After spending millions of dollars in disaster recovery money investigating a new road into a largely cut-off community near the Blue Mountains, a council is now reconsidering fixing the old one.

The Lithgow City Council (LCC) closed the only road into the Wolgan Valley in late 2022 due to the "high risk of harm" it said was posed by several landslides caused by wet weather.

A steep, four-wheel-drive route known as the Donkey Steps was created as an emergency access route for more than $4 million and has been the only way into the valley since.

Andrew Chalk says it is a "monumental waste of money" to keep investigating new road options. (Supplied: Andrew Chalk)

Wolgan Valley Association president Andrew Chalk said the community was immensely frustrated that it took years before fixing the existing road was taken seriously.

"We're back at the point we were three years ago," he said.

"The community has lost all confidence in the council's ability to manage this problem."

A billion-dollar fix

Engineering firm WSP Golder initially found it would cost more than $60 million to repair the 2.7-kilometre stretch of road to a level of "marginally acceptable" risk.

A $436,350 study, conducted by the firm and funded by disaster money, recommended that the council consider building a new route that would provide a more "resilient" and "cost-effective" solution.

After further investigations, the company increased the estimate to repair the section to $1 billion, or roughly $370,000 a metre.

LCC director of infrastructure Jonathon Edgecombe said more thorough investigations of the impacts of the landslides had bumped up the price.

The same engineering firm was contracted for more than $7 million to investigate new routes into the valley, which led to the approval of up to $385 million in disaster funding to restore access to the community.

Wolgan Road damage after rain in November 2022. (Supplied: Ask Roz Blue Mountains)

Meanwhile, a peer review of WSP's original findings was conducted by the company GHD, which found some of its assessments to be "unusual," and recommended a "comprehensive revision" of the road's landslide risk.

A subsequent investigation by GHD found the risk to be mostly "tolerable", and similar to other slopes on the NSW state road network.

GHD was contracted to complete a study that investigated temporarily reopening the road, which is forecast to be delivered in 12 weeks.

Road forward

The council had started discussions with both engineering firms about another study to look at how to reconstruct the old road.

The Wolgan Road was permanently closed in late 2022 after multiple landslides. (Supplied: Ask Roz Blue Mountains)

Despite acknowledging that the original WSP report was a "product of its time," Mr Edgecombe said the council would continue with its recommendation to progress new route investigations.

"We don't have mature enough data and design work in front of us to say that the old Wolgan Road or the new design option is the most cost effective, resilient, long-term and quickest possible pathway to see access restored to this community," he said.

"At some point in the very near future, we will have absolute certainty which of those options is most viable."

'Waste of money'

Independent geologist Marc Hendrickx said the GHD findings demonstrated new road options were redundant.

The emergency access road known as the Donkey Steps is the only way into the valley. (Supplied: Wolgan Valley Association)

"It says that the existing road is of a similar risk to many other slopes in the state … there are management procedures we can put in place to maintain that risk at a reasonable level," he said.

" There seems to be no justification at all for continuing any work on the new routes, and it is just going to be a complete waste of public money to continue to do so. "

Mr Chalk also believed pushing ahead with the new routes was a "monumental waste of money".

"The council still wants to go back and use the same consultants, WSP, that have led us into this great mess," he said.

But Mr Edgecombe said he had "absolute" confidence in the company to deliver good work.

"WSP has been assisting the council in the management of the Wolgan Road for nearly two decades," he said.

"[Its report] was authored at a time when the Wolgan Valley had been subject to several years of prolonged and sustained rainfall, and those slopes were actively moving at the time."

The luxury Emirates resort has been mothballed since June 2023 due to the closed road. (Supplied: Emirates Wolgan Valley)

WSP declined to comment.

Meanwhile, a spokesperson for NSW Minister for Roads Jenny Aitchison said she was "very sympathetic" to the local community.

"GHD's independent advice that far less funding will be required and that the road can be reopened more quickly is positive news," they said.

title: Government tells shoppers to buy Australian to save dwindling food industries
text:
Supermarket freezers are packed with more options than ever when it comes to frozen vegetables and chips.

But the colourful array of brands to suit different budgets hides a growing truth — Australian food manufacturing is under threat, and many customers are struggling to pay.

When it comes to food, national pride has become less of a priority, according to University of Tasmania associate professor Louise Grimmer.

Louise Grimmer has been observing the rise in supermarket private label brands. (ABC News: Maren Preuss)

"If someone says to us, do you look for Australian products and for local products? Of course, it's really important to support farmers," Dr Grimmer said.

"But when you've got households that are struggling and you might have two products and really there's not a lot of difference between them, but one is a lot cheaper … that's going to be the product that households select.

"And that might not be a locally grown or Australian product."

The federal government has pledged to spend $20 million on a campaign encouraging people to buy Australian.

It said it was part of a wider plan to use buying power to help businesses deliver better value and strengthen domestic industry and manufacturing.

The federal government is urging shoppers to support local producers by buying local. (ABC News: Laurissa Smith)

Tasmanian potato grower Matt Ryan said it could not come soon enough.

"You can walk around with a pair of worn-out socks or undies for a couple of weeks, and put up with it, but you can't go without food and the processed food industry is a big part of that," he said.

He admitted farmers and food manufacturers were struggling to deal with mounting costs and competition from cheaper imports, including potato chips.

These Coles branded chips are packed in Belgium from imported ingredients. (ABC News: Laurissa Smith)

Frozen imports growing

Last year, more than 218,000 tonnes of frozen cooked potatoes were imported into Australia.

That is a 25 per cent increase on 2023 levels, with frozen chips ending up in supermarkets, fast food outlets and takeaway shops.

It has been a case of deja vu for farmers in Australia's largest potato-growing state.

A tractor pulls a potato planter across a paddock near Thirlstane in Tasmania's north west. (ABC News: Laurissa Smith)

Back in 2005, farmers in Tasmania took aim at fast food chain McDonald's for cutting French fry contracts worth $10 million and importing product from New Zealand.

It led to one of Australia's largest agricultural protests from the apple isle to Canberra.

Experts say consumers hold a lot of power when it comes to keeping industries in Australia. (ABC Ballarat: Jarrod Watt)

The tractor-powered Fair Dinkum Food Campaign kicked off a national conversation about clearer country of origin labelling.

The major supermarkets were put on notice — and Mr Ryan said it paid off for a while.

"They chose to engage with the processors to have private label offerings with Australian-grown and actively promoted that," Mr Ryan said.

"Unfortunately, that's dissipated in recent years."

Supermarket private labels increase

The major supermarkets are stocking more of their own brands now.

Dr Grimmer has been tracking this trend.

"They're investing millions into private label or home brand products," she said.

"Part of that is to raise revenue, but the other aspect of it is all about getting loyal customers.

" A lot of the time we think especially frozen food is made in Australia, but what we're discovering more and more is these products are coming in from overseas. "

Frozen potato chips sold by the major supermarkets are increasingly processed overseas. (ABC News: Laurissa Smith)

So what percentage of their private label brands for frozen vegetables are Australian?

Woolworths said the majority of its frozen vegetable Own Brand range was locally sourced and had been for some time, while its tinned vegetable Own Brand range was sourced globally to help meet customer demand.

For frozen and canned vegetables, Coles said it worked with a mix of Australian and international suppliers to ensure consistent, year-round availability.

It also said geographic diversification helped protect customers from seasonal weather impacts and other supply chain disruptions.

Farmer advocate and former vegetable grower Richard Bovill. (ABC News: Laurissa Smith)

Richard Bovill knows a thing or two about retail buying strategies.

He was a distribution manager with Woolworths for 20 years before he switched to growing vegetables full-time in Tasmania's north west.

"It's only Australian consumers by their behaviour that can make these industries stay in Australia and exist," he said.

" If they are not buying the product, these factories disappear and when they're gone, they're gone for good. "

Farmers want shoppers to think about the origins of the food they buy. (ABC Ballarat: Jarrod Watt)

Vegetable processor Simplot said it worked with 300 growers across several states and was "proud to be the last Australian-grown frozen and shelf-stable vegetable provider of scale in the country".

Richard Bovill has leased out his vegetable farms and is now semi-retired.

He remains passionate about local food production.

"The federal government is talking about creating a manufacturing industry in Australia," he said.

"The first thing they need to look at is the ones we've got already and make sure we don't lose them."

title: Australia's biggest electric truck depot planned for busy freight route
text:
Transport is shaping up as one of Australia's biggest carbon challenges, and one of the hardest to solve.

Already the nation's third-largest source of greenhouse emissions, it is on track to become the highest-emitting sector by 2030 as electricity generation continues to clean up.

Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water 2023 projections show transport emissions will continue to rise slightly to 2030 while other sectors are expected to decline.

Within that, heavy road freight looms large.

"Australia is an extremely road freight-dependent country," said Daniel Bleakley, co-chief executive and co-founder of New Energy Transport.

"We're the second-most road-freight-dependent country in the world after the United States, and we also have the heaviest trucks in the world.

Daniel Bleakley and Fredrik Pehrsson are co-founders of New Energy Transport. (Supplied: New Energy Transport)

" If we can decarbonise heavy freight, we can make a huge impact on reducing transport emissions overall. "

New Energy Transport plans to establish a pilot fleet of heavy electric trucks in Wilton, south-west of Sydney, by the middle of 2026.

The company says it will be Australia's largest electric trucking depot.

The site will initially house up to 50 heavy electric prime movers, with plans to grow the fleet to 200 vehicles by 2031.

Wilton hub

The depot will be set up alongside Australia's busiest freight route — the Hume Highway.

A driver inspects a truck before the trial. (Supplied: New Energy Transport)

"It's a fantastic location because we've got good access to the Hume Highway and down to the Illawarra," Mr Bleakley said.

"There are around 5,000 trucks going up and down Picton Road to the Illawarra every day, and about 3,800 heavy trucks on the Hume Highway.

" We're positioning ourselves right in the middle of this extremely dense freight corridor. "

The depot will be powered by a mix of grid electricity and on-site solar, about 3 to 5 megawatts, with high-powered chargers capable of fully recharging the 600 to 700 kilowatt-hour truck batteries in under an hour.

"If we can run these electric trucks on low-cost renewable energy, we can reduce both emissions and the cost of heavy road freight," Mr Bleakley said.

Electric trucks 'light years ahead'

The concept was put to the test recently in what New Energy Transport believed was the longest single-charge electric truck delivery ever completed in Australia.

Wilton has been chosen as the site for Australia's largest heavy electric trucking depot. (Supplied: New Energy Transport)

Partnering with Multiquip, a major poultry transport and logistics company based in Liverpool, the team ran a 36-tonne electric prime mover from Picton to Beresfield in the Hunter and back again, about 480 kilometres on a single charge.

Multiquip national compliance manager David Muir, whose company supplied the chicken, said the test was a revelation.

"I was sceptical at the start. I still love proper diesel trucks," he said.

"But this thing was light-years ahead.

" It was significantly faster uphill, kept up with traffic easily, and the torque delivery was immediate. Each direction we saved about 20 minutes compared to our diesel trucks. "

Multiquip, which operates a fleet of about 500 trucks nationwide, found the electric truck not only matched diesel for range and cost, but offered surprising advantages.

"It was extremely quiet, [and] the driver said it was just so easy to drive," Mr Muir said.

"Less noise, less vibration, no exhaust fumes, it's a far better environment for drivers.

"They were able to arrive at their destination still feeling pretty fresh."

He said the trial showed that for hub-to-hub freight within a few hundred kilometres, electric trucks could already compete.

"The electricity it used compared to diesel was a fraction," Mr Muir said.

The company says the truck completed a 480-kilometre return trip between Picton and Beresfield on a single charge. (Supplied: New Energy Transport )

"It's early days, and infrastructure is the big challenge, but what we've seen so far is very promising."

Mr Bleakley believed those challenges were surmountable and that regional Australia could be at the forefront of powering a zero-emission freight future.

"If we transition the entire truck fleet to electric, we'll need about 20 per cent more electricity nationally," he said.

"But unlike diesel, that energy can be produced locally from renewables.

"That means we can make our freight network more resilient, cut costs, and keep food and goods moving even if global fuel supplies are disrupted."

title: Sporting clubs fear the worst as mining giant withdraws from Nhulunbuy
text:
As the remote Northern Territory town of Nhulunbuy prepares for the anticipated departure of mining giant Rio Tinto, long-standing local institutions such as the Gove Peninsula Tennis Club face an uncertain future.

Rio Tinto currently holds the lease to Nhulunbuy but will soon relinquish its control back to traditional owners and fully withdraw from the region by 2030.

The picturesque coastal town of Nhulunbuy, about 1,000 kilometres away east of Darwin, is home to more than 30 different sporting clubs serving its 3,200 residents.

Once thriving on the back of the mining sector, the tennis club and others like it now fear for their survival.

Pushed beyond breaking points

Nicky Mayers grew up with a tennis racket and wants to give young Territorians the same opportunities. (ABC News: Pete Garnish)

Long-term resident Nicky Mayers moved to the Gove Peninsula in the early 90s after meeting her Nhulunbuy-based husband during an overseas holiday.

She described it as "love at first sight", and as someone who grew up in regional Victoria with a tennis racket, she wanted to provide young people with the same opportunities she had.

Ms Mayers is the president of the 53-year-old Gove Peninsula Tennis Club which she describes as "struggling" despite its legacy of recognition.

"We currently have no running water and power for the clubhouse," she said.

The Arnhem Club is currently closed to patrons. (ABC News)

The tennis club is connected to the Arnhem Club, a venue which had recently been sold to new owners.

"We have an agreement with them [new owners] until 2032 to keep the courts… what the future holds after that, I don't think tennis courts will exist at all," Ms Mayers said.

Tennis Australia have previously awarded the club top honours, including two Newcombe Medals for outstanding contributions to tennis and the community.

Gove Peninsula Tennis Club has no running water or power in its clubhouse and its court is damaged. (Supplied: Nicky Mayer)

Ms Mayer said the uncertainty and lack of transparency had impacted their club with participation numbers falling from 600 people in 2013 to 280 today.

East Arnhem Land looks to develop tourism economy With the upcoming departure of Rio Tinto, communities on the Gove Peninsula are hoping yacht and cruise tourism could be the region's saving grace.

Other sporting club presidents, such as the BMX club, told the ABC the town's complex ownership and development rights meant different sports faced different challenges, with some likely to fold once their leases expired, while others faced an exodus of volunteers and decline in participation numbers.

Rio Tinto, in a statement, acknowledged the stress and anxiety their departure was causing to the community but said they were working with key stakeholders including the Gove Peninsula Future Reference Group and the Northern Land Council to ensure a smooth transition.

"This collaborative effort involves detailed consideration of asset and infrastructure transfers, future governance of the town, and arrangements for asset ownership," a spokesperson said.

More needs to be done

Tennis NT chief executive Tania Tandora says they are considering short, medium and long-term fixes. (ABC News: Dane Hirst)

Tennis Northern Territory chief executive Tania Tandora urged for patience but conceded there was little they could do.

"What we are doing … is providing feedback and engaging with the government around the master plan for the community as it changes over time and providing advice… [about] potential locations for a future public access tennis facility," she said.

Global mining group Rio Tinto has a refinery wharf in East Arnhem Land. (ABC News: Dane Hirst)

Back in Nhulunbuy, Ms Mayers says the impact of a sporting club stretches far beyond the court.

"Unfortunately, I think tennis is one component for the sport in town … if there's no sport … it will have a massive impact on why would anybody would want to move here," she said.

"Sports is also often used as a tool to keep people busy meaning less anti-social behaviour."

Gove Peninsula Tennis Club has no running water or power in its clubhouse and its court is damaged. (Supplied: Nicky Mayer)

Ms Mayers is urging the NT government and Tennis NT to invest more funding in remote and regional communities.

Ms Mayers said "one of the biggest hurdles" clubs in Nhulunbuy faced was trying to get an NT community benefit grant to fix up facilities as many were privately owned and therefore ineligible.

"Clubs can't apply for grants in that situation so its kind like feeling the town is neglected or listening or caring from a government perspective," she said.

NT Sports Minister Jinson Charls has been contacted for comment.

title: What will aged care fee changes mean for you? Here are the details
text:
Today marks the first day of the new fee structure for aged care.

A lot is changing. Self-funded retirees and some pensioners will be expected to pay more, saving the government $12.6 billion over the next 11 years.

Residential care and in-home care will both change.

The key principle is that the government will continue to pay for health-related costs, but people with financial means will pay more for other costs.

The changes apply to future recipients only, not to anybody currently receiving care.

This is how the reform will affect you.

In-home care

Care in the home will continue to be assessed on the basis of need.

There will be eight levels of support (instead of four currently), each with a different level of government funding, up to a maximum of $78,000 a year (instead of $60,000 currently).

That money can be thought of as an annual budget, which can be used to purchase services from an approved list.

What your budget can be spent on, versus what you will have to pay out of pocket, depends on your financial means and on the category of service.

The in-home care changes would see recipients pay more for independence supports and everyday living supports. (ABC News: Hugh Sando)

There are three categories:

Clinical care, such as nursing and occupational therapy

Independence supports, such as help with showering, dressing and medications

Everyday living supports, such as help with cleaning, gardening and meals

For clinical care, the government-funded budget can pay for the whole cost.

For independence supports and everyday living supports, you will be expected to pay some of the cost out of your own pocket, depending on your means (see table below).

Your situation What you will pay for Clinical care Independence support Everyday living Full pensioner 0% 5% 17.5% Part pensioner or health card holder 0% 5-50% 17.5-80% Self-funded retiree 0% 50% 80%

For the first time, the maximum price of home care services will be set by a government regulator to prevent over-charging.

In examples provided by the government, a full pensioner approved for level five support would end up paying for 6 per cent of their care, whereas a self-funded retiree who has no Commonwealth Seniors Health Card would pay 42 per cent.

A $25,000 payment will also be available to help recipients spend their final three months at home, and there will be a new 12-week program for help when recovering from an illness or injury.

Existing home care recipients, and those who are already approved, will switch to the new system but have a guarantee that they will not pay any more than they would under the old system.

The government has also lowered the maximum amount that home care recipients can be required to pay in administrative fees, leaving up to 27 per cent more leftover to spend on care. However, there are fears that providers will increase care prices by even more than 27 per cent.

Advocates for older Australians have also expressed concern about the way "non-clinical" care has been defined, with care recipients expected to make a partial contribution out of their own pockets towards showering and help taking medication, in some instances.

Residential care

The payment structure for residential care will stay the same, but the amounts will change.

Residents pay in three ways:

A basic daily fee paid by everyone

An additional daily fee paid by those with financial means

An accommodation charge, which can be paid daily or as a lump sum deposit

The basic daily fee, set at 85 per cent of the Age Pension, will not change.

The means-tested fee will be renamed the "non-clinical care" fee, reflecting the fact that the government covers clinical costs.

While the government will continue to cover clinical costs, a renamed "non-clinical" fee will see some residents pay for food and other amenities. (ABC News: Nance Haxton)

It will be paid by those with more than $500,000 in assets, or more than about $130,000 in income, or a combination.

It is a maximum of $101.16 a day and is paid for the first four years of care only.

The maximum accommodation charge will increase from $550,000 a room to $750,000 a room. Now, providers can seek government approval to charge more.

This can still be paid as a lump sum deposit, but providers will now be able to hold onto a portion of the deposit: 2 per cent of it each year for five years.

Finally, a $12.55 per day "hotelling" supplement, currently paid to providers by the government, will instead be paid by residents with more than $238,000 in assets, $95,400 in income, or a combination.

Just as before, the family home only counts towards the asset assessment up to the value of about $200,000.

In examples provided by the government, a full pensioner with few savings will continue to pay 17 per cent of the cost of his care, deducted from his pension. A self-funded retiree will pay 45 per cent.

Overall, three in 10 full pensioners will contribute more, and three in four part pensioners.

This will only apply to those who enter aged care from today.

Lifetime cap on fees

Nobody will be able to pay more than $130,000 in non-clinical care costs over their lifetime, covering both in-home care and residential care. That is higher than the current cap of about $80,000.

Why is the government doing this?

Aged care is one of the largest and fastest-growing areas of government spending, and the demand for aged care will keep increasing as the large baby boomer cohort gets older.

At the same time, both sides of politics and the aged care sector agree that existing levels of funding have not been sufficient to deliver the quality of care Australians expect.

In 2021, the Royal Commission into Aged Care Quality and Safety recommended a taxpayer-funded levy to boost funding.

But the government rejected that idea and has argued that residents should pay more if they can afford to do so. The government currently pays about $4 for every $1 paid by aged care residents, and $19 for every $1 paid by in-home care recipients.

These reforms would see the government pay $3.30 for every $1 paid by residents and $7.80 for every $1 paid by in-home care recipients.

The government also hopes that by charging more for in-home care, it can afford to provide support to more people and reduce waiting times. According to the most recent figures, 68,000 people are currently on the waitlist for an in-home care package.

title: Pen pals for 60 years, Joy and Diane live on opposite sides of the world
text:
Joy Doevendans and Diane Hatt are an unlikely pair of best friends, having lived their entire lives on opposite sides of the world.

Despite being separated by almost 12,000 kilometres — Ms Doevendans in Renmark, South Australia, and Ms Hatt in Enderby, Canada — the pair have maintained a friendship that has lasted for more than half a century.

"I think Diane knows more about me than my family," Ms Doevendans said.

"We consider each other family. If we don't hear from each other in a couple of days, we write and say, 'is everything OK?'" Ms Hatt said.

Diane and Joy inspect the first letter Diane ever sent, more than 50 years ago. (ABC Riverland: Matt Stephens)

The pair's connection began when, at the age of 12, Ms Hatt reached out to a friend of Ms Doevendans's, in search of an Australian pen pal.

"There was a newspaper called the Vancouver Sun and they had [an ad] where people could write in and just ask for pen pals," Ms Hatt said.

At the time, Ms Doevendans's friend had "too many pen pals" and decided to pass Ms Hatt's letter on to her instead.

"She said, 'I've got too many, would you like one?' and I said, 'Sure!' And I just happened to get Diane's," Ms Doevendans said.

What began as a letter sent on a whim in 1965 sparked the beginning of a 60-year friendship.

But it would take 15 years before the pair would meet the person on the other end of the pen.

Joy met Diane, and her husband Roger, for the first time in 1980, 15 years after Joy and Diane first began writing to each other. (Supplied: Diane Hatt)

Multi-generation affair

Always fascinated by Australia, Ms Hatt's mother, Ina, wanted to learn more about the country and decided to write to Ms Doevendans's mother, Florence.

Florence, a prolific letter writer in her own right, was thrilled to have someone to write to.

The mothers also went on to become long-time pen pals, creating a generational connection between the two families.

"I think if [our mothers] hadn't become pen pals, we would've lost touch," Ms Hatt said.

Diane and her mother, Ina, first met Joy and her mother, Florence, in Australia in 1980. (Supplied: Diane Hatt)

"I had seven pen pals, and I've only kept in contact with two."

The two families met in 1980 in the South Australian town of Renmark, marking a turning point in their relationship.

"My mum, my husband and I came over here to meet Joy and the rest of the family, and I remember thinking, 'I'm really nervous about meeting her,'" Ms Hatt said.

" The visit cemented our relationship again. "

Joy Doevendans and Diane Hatt have been best friends for 60 years. (ABC Riverland: Matt Stephens)

Technological advancements

While Ms Doevendans and Ms Hatt initially bonded over a shared love of writing, their mode of communicating eventually had to change with the times.

When they began writing to each other, they had to wait two weeks for a response, which made keeping up-to-date difficult.

"We would write at Christmas and maybe one other time, but we weren't really communicating all that much," Ms Hatt recalls.

But innovation in technology over the past 60 years has made things a lot easier, from email to messaging and even FaceTime.

Ms Doevendans and her husband have also visited Canada three times, including a trip in 2000. (Supplied: Diane Hatt)

"One time I got confused with the time zone and I phoned her at two in the morning," Ms Hatt said.

Ms Doevendans still has every letter Ms Hatt has written her, but had no choice but to switch from hard copy to online records as they switched to the digital world.

"I was actually printing [the letters] but then I had folders and folders full and I thought, 'nah, I've got to stop,'" she said.

Joy has kept every letter Diane has ever written to her. (ABC Riverland: Matt Stephens)

Final farewell

One of the benefits of living so far away from each other is the discretion that comes with it, something Ms Hatt cannot always rely on back home.

"You can tell each other secrets and know very well they're not going to get out in the community," she said.

Ms Hatt and her husband, Roger, just spent the past month visiting Ms Doevendans's family in South Australia.

Diane and Roger have visited much of South Australia, including Kangaroo Island. (Supplied: Diane Hatt)

While the pair made magical memories, Ms Hatt decided it was the last time they would visit Down Under.

"In an ideal world we would live six months here and six months in Canada," Ms Hatt said.

"How many people can say they have one of their best friends on the other side of the world?

"I do consider Joy one of my best friends … I consider her a sister."

title: 'Cowboy town' divided over keeping its heritage assets
text:
It was once the lifeblood of Carnarvon, but today, the One Mile Jetty sits crumbling at the heart of the heritage precinct that was built to celebrate it.

Built in 1897, it connected the town, 890 kilometres north of Perth, to the outside world before the first roads were built. It later became a popular fishing spot for generations of Carnarvon locals and visitors.

But in 2017, the aging timber structure was declared a safety risk and shut off to the public.

A refurbishment is expected to begin next year, with plans for part of the jetty to be publicly accessible by 2027 — a decade after it was closed.

With federal funding going towards a glitzy new waterfront development, locals are disappointed about the jetty's future, but they are not yet giving up on seeing their treasured heirloom shine again.

Memories of sunny days and manta rays

When Jamie Venner was growing up, he spent much of his childhood at the jetty.

"It was an institution for kids growing up in Carnarvon for sure and was a bit of a pretty big tourism draw," he said.

Jamie Venner says the town's One Mile Jetty was "an institution". (Supplied: Jamie Venner)

"Carnarvon's got a long history — it goes back to like a western era, it was a cowboy kind of a town.

"We don't need anything new and flash, we just need to preserve the things that we've got and I think tourists appreciate that — they don't want to go sit in a flash cafe or a wine bar or something, they've got that where they come from."

Options for full restoration

In 2021, the state government allocated $8.7 million to repair — rather than rebuild — the jetty after it was lashed by Cyclone Seroja.

In stage 1, $4.2 million went to an emergency deconstruction of the intertidal and waterside parts and salvaging of fallen timbers to avoid navigational hazards.

It left only 700 metres of the once mighty 1,450-metre structure standing.

The One Mile Jetty has been closed since 2017. (ABC News: Kelsey Reid)

The long-awaited stage 2 will see up to 200m of the jetty restored – but it will not extend beyond marshland to reach the water.

A business report by Acil Allen in 2022 weighed up 10 potential options for a stage 3, concluding that none of the options were financially viable.

"The deterioration in the asset condition of the Carnarvon One Mile Jetty, leading to the eventual removal of the majority of the structure for community safety reasons, is the outcome of a series of decisions over more than 30 years," the report stated.

The Department of Transport confirmed it did not intend to pursue any further rebuild or restoration past stage 2.

Heritage assets left to decay

With the jetty’s fate all but sealed, the Shire of Carnarvon is not pursuing further state government funding.

"Given the significant whole-of-life costs and risks, we are not seeking to take on the ongoing management and maintenance of the jetty," said Shire CEO Mandy Dexter.

Mandy Dexter says the shire requires state government support to restore its heritage attractions. (ABC News: Kelsey Reid)

"Our focus is completing the Tramway Bridge — a key town asset that connects directly to the Jetty’s heritage story."

Another aging heritage asset, the Tramway Bridge was built in 1899 to connect the jetty to the centre of town.

It is now closed to the public after also falling into disrepair.

Stage 1 works on the Tramway Bridge have been federally funded. (ABC News: Kelsey Reid)

Recently, the Shire of Carnarvon was awarded $15.5 million in funding from the federal government under the regional Precincts and Partnerships Program (rPPP).

While most will go to new developments, $3.7 million was allocated for bridge repairs, but not enough to complete the project.

Carnarvon's Tramway Bridge connected the town to the One Mile Jetty. (ABC News: Kelsey Reid)

In the hope that one of its heritage assets could once again open to the public, the shire attempted to transfer the jetty repair money to the Tramway Bridge repair.

The motion failed to pass the council.

Carnarvon Heritage Group chair and shire councillor Dudley Maslen said he was frustrated by the situation.

"We're not building the Sydney Harbour Bridge, but they're doing their best to make it look that way," he said.

Dudley Maslen is frustrated at the lack of progress to fix the One Mile Jetty. (ABC News: Kelsey Reid)

The ripple effect

Carnarvon has about 6,500 residents and some locals say the combination of having few attractions, tough liquor laws and high crime have marred the town's reputation.

It has left tourism operators and caravan parks reporting numbers down from previous years.

Carnarvon is located 890km north of Perth in the Gascoyne region. (ABC News: Kelsey Reid)

Jo Bumbak has spent the past 26 years running her business, which is targeted towards tourists.

This summer will be her last.

A decline in visitor numbers over the past few years left her car park empty last school holidays, and she said the business was no longer viable.

Jo Bumbak will close her preserves shop and cafe at the end of January. (ABC News: Kelsey Reid)

"Carnarvon doesn't have a lot of experiences, which is what the new tourist is chasing," she said.

" The tourism dollars are just driving past every hour of the day and night, and Carnarvon is really missing out, and we need state help. "

Ms Bumbak has been a passionate advocate for the jetty and fundraised $10,000 last year through her business.

She aims to start a fundraiser involving making and selling one mile of rocky road that will be packaged up and sold to raise more money for the jetty.

Jo Bumbak has repurposed seconds produce in Carnarvon for more than two decades. (ABC News: Kelsey Reid)

She would like to see the jetty restored to its former glory.

"It is the greatest tourism asset that Carnarvon has and yet we can't get the support to fully fix this jetty," Ms Bumbak said.

"It's the one thing that people love to come and fish off, they love to swim off it, jump off it, walk on it, kite surf off it.

"The stories that people share today bring back all those memories and people want to experience that.

"And to me that is extremely valuable for tourism."

Looking to the future

DG Corp's Pier Development received more than half of a recent $15.5 million funding pool for Carnarvon. (Supplied: DG Corp)

Instead of putting all of the federal government's $15.5 million funding to the town's heritage assets, the lion's share will go towards a brand new development dubbed "The Pier".

The development proposes to build permanent housing, resort-style accommodation and a bar/bistro.

Private developer DG Corp has been awarded the tender, but state government approvals have not been made yet.

"It's going to happen and I'm pretty excited about it because we need that housing, both holiday and workforce housing," Shire President Eddie Smith said.

"It's probably the best piece of land in Carnarvon."

Eddie Smith is hopeful a new development in the town will attract more tourism. (ABC News: Kelsey Reid)

Regional tourism body Australia's Coral Coast chief executive David O'Malley agreed accommodation was an issue and more luxurious options could lure in visitors.

"We need to attract the high value travellers and that basically means the people who spend more money," he said.

title: Why are women always the ones being sawn in half in magic shows?
text:
Most Melburnians are fondly familiar with State Library Victoria's iconic domed reading room, where students study in creaky wooden chairs under green bankers' lamps and tourists circle in the galleries above.

But hidden in the maze of corridors, electronic security doors, and tunnels below is an unexpected archive of magical treasures.

The WG Alma Conjuring Collection is home to thousands of books, magazines, posters, memorabilia, scale models and photographs — all about magic and magicians.

"It is a bit different to our normal library collections," says librarian Jodi Kok.

"It has books, journals, stuff that you'd expect to find here. But it also has things like posters, tricks, scale models, and [prop] skulls."

The Conjuring Collection contains about 2,000 books on magic, 1,500 photographs, 300 posters and more than 400 detailed research files on individual magicians. ( )

Melbourne-born magic man

Will Alma was a stage magician born in Malvern, Victoria, in 1904. Both his parents were magicians, but after his father left his mother and moved to Hawaii to start a new family, Alma's mother was not keen for her son to follow in his father's footsteps.

But the boy had already caught the magic bug, and performed his first show at just 15 years of age in the local church.

Originally named Oswald George William Bishop, the magician changed his name to Will Alma by deed poll in 1949. ( ) Will took after his father, who performed as Alma, the Court Magician. ( ) Will Alma, around 1956, performing his signature trick of swallowing razor blades. ( )

Alma became one of Australia's most well-known magicians of the 20th century, having particular success as a designer and manufacturer of magic tricks, props and devices. The most famous of his customers was "The Great Levante" — a world-renowned illusionist who Alma toured with in the 1940s.

Will Alma was also a certified magic fanboy and prolific collector of conjuring memorabilia.

Stream The Art Of... on ABC iview Hosted by Namila Benson, the ABC's bold and vibrant arts and culture show The Art Of… returns for another season, taking you into the studios, brains and hearts of some of Australia's most exciting creators.

The book that started it all for Alma was Magic Made Easy by London-born international superstar magician David Devant, published in 1909. This magic manual is among the treasures that Alma accumulated over his life, but many of the items in the collection tell stories from closer to home.

Alma compiled detailed files on hundreds of local magicians, providing invaluable details of the lives and careers of many magicians whose stories may otherwise have gone unrecorded — his collection now acts as a kind of history of the Australian magic scene.

Women in magic

For Australian theatre-goers in the 1900s, The Incomparable Sloggetts would have been a familiar name.

Founded by patriarch Charles Sloggett in 1911, the magic troupe travelled all over the country.

"Charles toured for about 60 years and during that time he had a number of wives — not at once!" says Kok.

The Sloggetts toured Australia for decades under the slogan, "everything new except the name!". ( )

"And one of his signature tricks was actually decapitating a wife, and the head would roll into the crowd, but would be a cabbage by the time it appeared."

However, Charles Sloggett's second wife, Athena Pallas, was not content to just be decapitated on stage night after night.

Three of Sloggett's four wives were magicians in their own right, and Pallas was possibly the first professional solo female magician in Australian history. She was skilled at conjuring, mind reading, snake charming and even ventriloquism.

Alma had noticed that most of the Sloggett material didn't mention Pallas, so he wrote to her directly to create a file on her; their correspondence is part of the collection.

"She talks about having a really hard life touring with Charles," explains Kok.

"She had two children with him; he had other children. So she was looking after children, she was baking bread for them, she was making butter, she was driving everywhere, looking after the animals.

"She even made the tents that they would sometimes take with them if they performed in a place that didn't have a town hall."

Pallas left Sloggett in 1941 and went on to pursue her own career.

Athena Pallas was a skilled conjurer, ventriloquist and snake charmer. ( )

But the lives and careers of 20th-century female magicians and assistants are often sidelined in what has traditionally been a male-dominated profession.

Indeed, as Jodi Kok explains, many tricks and tropes of traditional stage conjuring take a decidedly gendered tone.

The famous "buzz saw illusion" — in which a male magician saws a glamorous assistant in half live on stage — is a particularly enduring trope.

First staged by English magician PT Selbit in 1921, the trick appeared to become political in the years after women won the right to vote.

"One of his gimmicks was he actually offered to pay the suffragette Christabel Pankhurst to appear on stage and be sawn in half. She did not agree," says Kok.

PT Selbit performing his "sawing a woman in half trick". ( )

" There was something around the culture there that I think was maybe a little misogynistic … It always seems to be a woman who's sawn in half. "

The bequest

When Will Alma died at the age of 89 in 1993, his vast collection was bequeathed to State Library Victoria — but not without several stipulations.

One is that the collection always be referred to as a "conjuring" collection, rather than a "magic" collection.

"I think the word conjuring is really important," says Jodi Kok.

"It's not occult stuff, even though some tricks sort of use that spiritual language, that's not what it's about."

The sawing in half trick was a turning point in the history of magic, heralding a more sensational and shocking style. ( )

Another stipulation of the bequest was that whenever items are exhibited, the library must do so in a way that does not give away trade secrets to the public en masse.

"But the great thing about this collection is, if you wanted to know how [a trick] was done, you could come in, look at the books, the journals […] and you could study up and find out," she says.

"But then you'd need to find a woman who was willing to be sawn in half."

Watch the new season of The Art of... free on ABC TV and ABC iview.

title: Silence from Canberra Liberals leader only making a bad situation worse
text:
It was the subtlest of changes that few noticed — the appearance of two new microphones on the crossbench of the ACT Legislative Assembly.

They emerged in the hours after Elizabeth Lee and Peter Cain were suspended from the Canberra Liberals party room.

When it became clear Ms Lee and Mr Cain remained committed to their party, albeit on the outer, the microphones were promptly removed after just a day.

But it was a stark reminder; anything can happen in politics.

And after the events of this week, Ms Lee, the party's former leader, and Mr Cain, a former shadow minister, feel closer to the crossbench than ever before.

The unlikely vote that caused tensions to boil over

There's been simmering tensions within the Canberra Liberals for some time.

Liberal party room indefinitely suspends former leader, backbencher Two backbenches have been suspended indefinitely from the Canberra Liberals party room.

The decision to suspend the two backbenchers came almost exactly a year to the day from Leanne Castley's successful tilt for the party's leadership — despite previously having assured Ms Lee of her support.

It also came just months after Mr Cain quit shadow cabinet, citing concerns over the party's leadership and alluding to issues around workplace culture.

It's been a matter of when, not if, the tensions were going to come to a head.

But it was an unlikely, largely procedural vote on the assembly's sitting calendar for next year that was the final straw.

The long-held Liberal principle?

Ms Lee and Mr Cain voted differently to their party colleagues — wanting to preserve the number of sitting weeks for next year at 13, rather than dropping to 12.

And, in so doing, exercised a long Liberal tradition of being able to cross the floor.

Peter Cain said he was incredibly surprised to be suspended from the party room. (ABC News: Toby Hunt)

In the words of Liberal senator Sarah Henderson: "Being able to cross the floor is a very important principle in the Liberal Party".

But it appears, on the face of it, doing just that saw Ms Castley banish Ms Lee and Mr Cain from her party room.

What makes this situation more perplexing is Ms Castley's past comments saying backbenchers were indeed allowed to cross the floor.

"Well, as backbenchers, they have that opportunity of course," she told ABC's Stateline in September.

The missing leader

Leanne Castley has so far refused to explain why the backbenchers were suspended. (ABC News: Stuart Carnegie)

Other than two brief written statements, Ms Castley has been silent on the matter.

The ABC attempted to get answers from her as she arrived at the assembly on Thursday morning — almost 48 hours on from her decision.

"I will not talk about party room stuff with you today," Ms Castley said.

But when asked if the custom of allowing Liberal backbenchers to cross the floor was not the case in the Canberra Liberals, she responded: "Of course it is the case in the Canberra Liberals."

It's a response that raises far more questions.

It also alludes, rather strongly, that there is something much greater at play here.

Loading...

The longer Ms Castley stays silent, the more attention the feud gathers.

And while she is silent, the space is being filled by Ms Lee and Mr Cain's side of the story — they've fronted the media several times to explain their version of events.

Ms Castley insists she won't be making any public comments, saying "litigating these issues publicly is not helpful in showing a commitment to restoring trust."

But it's hard to see how staying silent is helping Canberrans build trust in her party and her as the ACT's alternative chief minister.

Labor's bad day overshadowed

Labor's Chris Steel was also not having a good day on Thursday. (ABC News: Matt Roberts)

In Ms Castley's statement on Thursday, she noted herself: "The events of this week have, unfortunately, diverted attention from the issues that matter most to the people of the ACT."

And, in an own goal for the Liberals, a perfect example of attention being diverted from where it should have been was presented that same day.

Canberrans already knew the launch of the government's MyWay+ ticketing system was plagued by software bugs and hardware issues, but a scathing report by an assembly committee laid bare the shortcomings.

Transport Minister Chris Steel was censured by the assembly over the part he played in the rollout.

It was the first time the assembly had censured an MLA since 2011.

The censure carries no ongoing consequences aside from reputational damage, but the damage done this week felt like a bit of a blip amongst the implosion of the opposition.

However, with the Greens out of a formal coalition with Labor, Mr Steel's censure is evidence of the new makeup of the assembly at play.

We can expect to see more of this.

Unknown path ahead

There's a whole month before the assembly next sits — the last sitting week of the year.

But before then, Liberal MLAs are due to meet to attempt to resolve their internal issues.

Elizabeth Lee says she still remains faithful to the Liberal Party. (ABC News: Ian Cutmore)

It's hard to know what happens from there — even if Ms Lee and Mr Cain are allowed back into the party room, it would be an extremely awkward environment.

So awkward it would almost certainly be unworkable.

But if the Canberra Liberals ever want to be seen as a viable alternative to Labor in the ACT, they'll want to quickly put this saga behind them.

Right now, it's hard to see how they'll do that.
