title: ‘A little bit nerve-racking’: How students think they fared in QCE’s largest exam
text:
In the week of a Caesar switch-up that devastated ancient history students and wild weather that knocked out half a dozen campuses for a day, students across Queensland also faced the state’s biggest exam.

Almost 28,000 year 12 students sat their external English exams on Tuesday, with a passing grade in the subject mandatory for their Queensland Certificate of Education.

In Brisbane’s west, students at The Gap State High School said they felt well-prepared for the test, even finding the questions “not too hard”.

The Gap State High School Students Ella Gjerek (left) and Amelia Lynch (right). Credit: Catherine Strohfeldt

“We’d studied Macbeth for the past term, [and] they’ve been using Macbeth for a long time, so it’s a little bit nerve-racking to see what questions they’ve come up with, but I knew it would work out,” school captain Amelia Lynch said.

title: Nationals move to scrap Net Zero
text:
The Nationals have voted to scrap net zero from their policy platform, with federal MPs expected to do the same on Sunday ahead of wider Coalition talks on energy policy.

The motion to “abandon support for a net zero mandate” was passed at the party’s Federal Council meeting in Canberra on Saturday.

Its passing does not bind the party’s federal MPs to do the same, however the outcome is expected to be similar when the group meets on Sunday morning.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Saturday’s motion does not vanquish all support for emissions reductions, with the party voting to support a “flexible policy framework that caters for emissions reductions, while growing and protecting key industries”.

Ahead of the vote, Nationals leader David Littleproud told members the resolution was “eminently sensible”.

“Today you’ll debate a resolution, an eminently sensible resolution, around making sure we have a commonsense solution to our energy, to our climate. We believe in maintaining and protecting our climate and our environment. There are practical ways,” he said.

“We’re not walking away from reducing emissions, but we can do it a better, fairer, cheaper way. We can align ourselves with the world as the world pivots from an arbitrary target to using common sense, making sure that they don’t destroy their economies.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

“We can do that, calm and considered, and we work with our coalition partners.

“And I’ve made it clear with Sussan Ley that while we respect the sovereignty of their room, we’ve asked her to respect the sovereignty of our room. And we’ve come together in a considered way to work together. And that is the endeavour that we will start tomorrow morning at 9am.”

Net Zero has been a growing sore point within the broader Coalition, as well as within the two parties.

Since becoming opposition leader, Ms Ley has refused to take a concrete stance on whether Australia should strive to reach net zero emissions by 2050.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Instead, she has committed to a blanket policy review, arguing it is needed after the Coalition’s decimation at the federal election in May.

While some moderates within the Liberal Party are reportedly happy to keep a watered-down version of the policy, many high profile MPs, including now-backbencher Andrew Hastie, have taken a public stance in firm opposition.

Barnaby Joyce flagged the Nationals’ support of Net Zero as a major reason behind his decision to take a break from the party room.

“Our position in continuing to support net zero with the massive schism and hurt to my electorate, to small businesses, to the environment, to the poor, to the defence of Australia and creating hate between lifelong friends in my community makes continuing in the Nationals’ Party Room in Canberra under this policy untenable,” he said last month.

More to come

title: Caravan couple's grim moment shows secret truth about life on the road
text:
Caravanning is becoming increasingly popular as Aussies hit the open road and document their seemingly glamorous holidays travelling around our vast country. Images of spectacular landscapes and exciting wildlife encounters flood social media, leaving many to wonder if they should also jump on the caravanning bandwagon.

But if you needed a little shade from the light shining on caravanning holidays right now, this video might provide a reality check.

A truckie from Grafton in northern NSW captured the moment his wife Korrine was dumping the family's caravan toilet, lovingly referred to as the 'devil's suitcase', into a campground dump point, and the experience was so horrendous, she was left "dry heaving" by the side of the road.

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

"I was towing the caravan out and my wife said we'd better call in and empty the toilet on the way out," Brenton Smith told Yahoo News. "She jumped out, and that's when I could see her heaving... The smell from the pit got her, and I think some splashed up on her hand. Me and the two kids were just in the car laughing.

"She's got a bit of a weak stomach at the best of times... It can't be that bad."

Notably, Brenton admitted he hasn't yet done the toilet emptying task.

Have you had a gross experience emptying your caravan toilet? Contact sophie.coghill@yahooinc.com

Truckie claims dumping the caravan toilet is 'as bad as it gets'

Brenton and his family, who travelled over 260 kilometres on their maiden journey in their new caravan, were excited about the prospect of exploring more of Australia. Despite it being his first caravan journey with his family, Brenton has been "camping all his life" and said the dumping of the caravan toilet is "as bad as it gets".

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

"Being able to just have a shower and everything in our own little house on wheels, it's awesome," he said. "I'd say the toilet dumping is the worst of it. It's usually very comfortable."

Korrine isn't the first to be filmed tackling the horrendous task, with Sydney woman Brooke Goosen caught on camera dumping her family's toilet into a designated dump site last year. She told Yahoo News, "it was foul" and found the whole system "outdated".

"If we're getting rockets into space, surely there's a better way," she said.

Campers frequently say how horrendous it is to dump the waste from their caravan. Source: Instagram/goosens_are_trippin & Moysoutdoors

Advertisement Advertisement

Advertisement Advertisement

Ashley Moy, a dad who was staying in Alice Springs with his family in June, had to go one step further and put his hand down the dumping site after the cap of his caravan toilet fell in along with the waste. A video captured him armed with a pair of tongs standing by the dump site as he tightly wound up his sleeves and plunged his arm down to retrieve the cap.

He told Yahoo News it was too "important" to leave behind. He managed to grab it, but was left gagging from his efforts.
